Award.AwardTitle: NETS: SMALL: Collaborative Research: Protocol Stacks Design and Evolution: The Role of Layering and Modularity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Network protocol stacks typically follow a multi-layer hierarchical architecture. What determines the required number of layers, or the number of protocols at each layer? The space of applications, services and user expectations (at the top layer) and the space of elementary functions (at the bottom layer) are constantly evolving -- how does this dynamic environment affect the organization of layered protocol stacks? What determines the evolvability of a protocol stack in the presence of changes? How does evolvability relate to other important system-wide properties such as robustness (the ability to deal with unexpected change), optimality and modularity? These are some of the high-level questions that this research project focuses on.

Intellectual Merit: This research seeks to reexamine the fundamentals of protocols design and investigate the role of and dependencies between several central concepts: layering, modularity, complexity, robustness, optimality. The central theme in this research, however, is evolution -- networking architectures are not designed to work in a static environment. Applications, services, user expectations, communication and computing technologies, as well as the underlying economics, are all in a constant state of flux.

Rather than rely on a single modeling framework, this research starts with two preliminary models, referred to as Stratum and Lexis. The two models share some features but are also significantly different and complementary. They both capture the time-varying character of a layered design process aiming to support a dynamic set of applications from an underlying set of (also dynamic) elementary functions. Stratum is more constrained than Lexis as it considers, first, a specific ordering for the available building blocks, and second, an endogenous model for the ``death rate'' of existing applications. Lexis, on the other hand, is more general and more abstract, and captures how a time-varying set of regular expressions can be constructed hierarchically from a time-varying alphabet, re-using simpler regular expressions as much as possible.
The Stratum and Lexis models are initial steps towards developing a base understanding of what factors influence the evolvability and sustainability of protocols. With this base in place, further domain-specific insight can be developed and yield targeted guidelines for the design of future network protocols.

Broader Impact: There are currently four large NSF-funded Future Internet Architecture (FIA) projects that pursue a ``clean-slate'' design approach for a future Internet that is more robust, secure, evolvable, etc. A goal of this research is to both inform and learn from the efforts of the four FIA projects.

The broader impact of this project also includes the release of two extensible simulators (corresponding to Stratum and Lexis) that will allow students and instructors to experiment with how network architectures evolve in dynamic environments and under optimization objectives and constraints. No such tools are available today.

Additionally, this project has a significant inter-disciplinary component in both its ?inputs and outputs.? Specifically, much of the prior work behind this research (inputs) has originated in economics, physics and evolutionary biology. Conversely, the project's results (outputs) are likely to be relevant to other disciplines such as software engineering, smart manufacturing and the science of organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major goal of this project has been to understand the factors that contribute to a protocol’s success and its ability to evolve and accommodate changes. The development and adoption of new protocols (or of extensions to existing protocols) is arguably central to the Internet’s evolution. However, and in spite of over 40 years of experience with this process, the networking community has limited understanding of what factors may contribute to a protocol’s success. A sound technical design and a well-grounded purpose are obviously important, but there are many examples of failures that met those two criteria. What other factors affect a protocol’s likelihood of success, and under what circumstances? This project investigated this question in part through a statistical approach, based on analyzing a set of Internet standard documents, IETF RFCs. These RFCs were characterized using a number of key features, followed by an analysis of the association between those features and positive or negative odds for the success of each protocol. The high-level results of this analysis are intuitive, e.g., protocols that call for Internet-wide adoption face greater challenges. Focusing on more targeted subsets of protocols revealed more subtle and possibly more interesting differences between areas of the Internet landscape. The project also applied this prediction framework to IPv6 using different “what-if” scenarios to explore what might have affected its deployment. The dataset that was created for this study is publicly available.

 

A related activity that grew out of this broader effort was a more targeted case study comparing the IS-IS and OSPF protocols; two routing protocols with similar functionality, which were developed around the same time but exhibit important design differences.  Their co-existence over a period of more than 20 years offers a unique opportunity to explore how design differences may affect a protocol’s evolution (they both sought to incorporate a similar set of extensions).   The investigation confirmed the initial intuition that one protocol simpler initial design indeed translated into lower design and implementation costs, but that the greater flexibility (and higher complexity) of the second design allowed it to better (at a lower cost) absorb important changes.  Of note though, was the fact that in spite of those differences, both protocols were able to evolve, albeit in a very different way.  In particular, initial simplicity, even or because it means less flexibility, can attract a large and dedicated following of software developers, who then have a vested interest in ensuring the persistence of the protocol even if it requires major changes.  Hence, ensuring its long-term survival.

 

Another goal of this project was to investigate the evolution of layered protocol stacks and architectures, focusing on fundamental questions such as: What determines the required number of layers or the number of protocols at each layer? What determines the evolvability of a protocol stack? How does this evolvability relate to other system-wide properties such as robustness, optimality, and modularity? When and why does a protocol stack get the shape of an hourglass? When do the protocols at the waist of that hourglass become “ossified”, meaning that they stop evolving? And when is it better to replace an incumbent architecture with a new, “clean-slate” architecture? The project has developed an abstract modeling framework, referred to as Lexis, that can provide valuable insights about the previous questions. One of the most interesting results of this investigation has been that the evolution of a layered network architecture (not only the Internet architecture) is expected to take the shape of an hourglass with a small number of highly central protocols in the middle layers and that those protocols gradually become very difficult to modify or replace, under the following conditions: a) the architecture evolves by trying to minimize the cost of adopting any new applications or services, and b) those new applications or services are created through an evolutionary process that proceeds through small, incremental changes that are selected only if they offer a competitive advantage.  

 

Overall, the project has resulted in a number of peer-reviewed publications at top-tier conferences and journals. Further, it has supported in part the graduate studies of four Ph.D. students, one of whom has already graduated while the others will graduate in 2018 or 2019. The project also inspired new ideas and approaches in the undergraduate and graduate courses taught by the two PIs. Finally, the project has contributed to scientific disciplines outside the computer networking area, including data mining, bioinformatics, network science, and more generally, disciplines that study the evolution of hierarchical complex systems.
